clinical_study.brief_title: Surgically Induced Astigmatism of Temporal Versus Nasal Clear Corneal Phacoemulsification

lead_sponsor.agency: Shahid Beheshti University of Medical Sciences

clinical_study.source: Shahid Beheshti University of Medical Sciences

brief_summary.textblock: To compare the short-term astigmatic outcomes of phacoemulsification cataract surgery and intraocular lens implantation using temporal versus nasal clear corneal incisions.

detailed_description.textblock: In a clinical trial, consecutive eyes with senile cataract underwent phacoemulsification with implantation of a 6.0 mm foldable hydrophobic acrylic intraocular lens through a 3.2 mm horizontal clear cornea incision at 180 degrees (temporal incision in right eyes, nasal incision in left eyes). Keratometric astigmatism was measured preoperatively and one and four weeks and 6 months after surgery. Surgically induced astigmatism (SIA) was calculated by the vector analysis method using the Holladay-Cravy-Koch formula. Patients with history of diabetes mellitus, connective tissue disorders, steroid use, previous ocular surgery, with the rule astigmatism >1D, pseudoexfoliation and any corneal pathology were excluded.

primary_outcome.time_frame: At 1 and 4 weeks and 6 month after surgery

intervention.description: clear cornea phacoemulsification and intraocular lens implantation using temporal or nasal incisions respectively

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All the patients with senile cataract
Exclusion Criteria:
- Previously operated eyes
- Presence of corneal pathology
- Pseudo exfoliation
- With-the-rule (WTR) astigmatism >1 D
- Presence of diabetes mellitus
- History of connective tissue disease
- Consumption of systemic steroids
